error.signature: Hydration failed because the server rendered HTML didn't match the client.
error.regex: (?:Hydration failed|Text content does not match server-rendered HTML|There was an error while hydrating)

verdict.summary: Server and client render different HTML. Common causes: browser-only APIs (window, localStorage), date/time rendering, browser extensions injecting elements, and conditional rendering based on client state.

dead_ends.action: Adding suppressHydrationWarning to the root element
dead_ends.why_fails: suppressHydrationWarning only suppresses text content mismatches on a single element. It does not fix structural mismatches (different elements, different number of children). It masks the problem rather than fixing it.
dead_ends.common_misconception: suppressHydrationWarning is a global fix for all hydration errors.

dead_ends.action: Wrapping everything in useEffect to skip server rendering
dead_ends.why_fails: Moving all rendering to useEffect means nothing renders on the server, defeating the purpose of SSR entirely. The page appears blank until JavaScript loads, hurting performance and SEO.
dead_ends.common_misconception: SSR is optional when it is the core feature of the framework being used.

dead_ends.action: Disabling React strict mode to suppress the error
dead_ends.why_fails: Strict mode does not cause hydration errors. It double-invokes effects to catch bugs, but hydration mismatches are real rendering inconsistencies. Disabling strict mode does not fix them.
dead_ends.common_misconception: Strict mode causes hydration errors because of double rendering.

workarounds.action: Use a mounted state to defer client-only rendering
workarounds.how: const [mounted, setMounted] = useState(false); useEffect(() => setMounted(true), []); if (!mounted) return <ServerFallback />; return <ClientContent />; This renders the same fallback on server and client until hydration completes.
workarounds.tradeoff: Slight flash of fallback content; client-specific content appears after hydration

workarounds.action: Move browser-only APIs behind typeof window checks
workarounds.how: const value = typeof window !== 'undefined' ? window.localStorage.getItem('key') : null; This ensures server and client render the same default value initially.

workarounds.action: Use next/dynamic with ssr: false for truly client-only components
workarounds.how: const ClientOnly = dynamic(() => import('./ClientOnly'), { ssr: false }); This skips server rendering for components that fundamentally cannot run on the server (maps, editors, etc.).
workarounds.tradeoff: Component is not rendered during SSR; may cause layout shift
